body: Would you like to take a crack at this one? Otherwise I have to go and install Debian 6.0.1 somewhere.

This report might be bogus, [L89](https://github.com/EllisLab/CodeIgniter/blob/develop/system/core/Utf8.php#L89) makes use of the error suppression operator already (and `//ignore`). I wonder why the error is being reported at all. Maybe via the error handler callback?

@kenjis

Yeah, that's the point: NOTICEs are suppressed via `@` (you should not get any notice anyway) _and_ the use of `//IGNORE` instructs `iconv()` to not give any E_NOTICE as well.

So even if PHP 5.3 `iconv()` does not support `//IGNORE` on the reporters Debian system, no E_NOTICE should be given because of error suppression.

_Edit:_ Maybe the input is not UTF-8 so that contains the illegal character (obviously reading the notice text again). I've overlooked that aspect, what is the input encoding anyway?

I just got this too:

ERROR - 2011-08-29 13:37:33 --> Severity: Notice --> iconv(): Detected an illegal character in input string /var/fog/apps/286/pyrocms.com/system/codeigniter/core/Utf8.php 89

I added #342 as pull request, for those who have the problem please check it. You see the errors in the log by design, the error handler is asking the log to save them as `ERROR`. As long as you have that level enabled for your log you will see them.

To work around that, the error handler now checks if the error was originally suppressed with `@` and if so changes the severity to `SCREAM` which corresponds to `5` in `$config['log_threshold']`. As long as you don't set that configuration setting to 5, you should not see these notices any longer. Please test.

@CrazyLionHeart: I tested that as well. It does not get truncated, at least not for PHP 5.3 and 5.2. PHP 5.4 drops the whole input string, which seems fair as it's not UTF-8. [Demo across PHP versions](http://codepad.viper-7.com/yNNQMA).

I had a pull request in the bitbucket repo for this issue, this was actually a big problem with an application I am working on where data was being dropped while posting directly to the app over an api. I did a lot of digging and found that it is actually a problem with the glibc implementation of iconv()... which is found on most servers, versus the libiconv implementation which runs on most localhost settings, making it difficult to replicate.

I just added a pull request here, let me know what you think... https://github.com/EllisLab/CodeIgniter/pull/372
I have a little more of a description in the summary of the pull request, but i was basing that conclusion off of this: https://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=48147

## From that above bug report

 [2009-05-07 13:58 UTC] jani@php.net
We still can't fix bugs in glibc iconv implementation. Try this on 
command line and you get same results:

# iconv -f utf-8 -t iso-8859-1 iconv.html > /dev/null

iconv: illegal input sequence at position 3589

# iconv -f utf-8 -t iso-8859-1//IGNORE iconv.html > /dev/null

iconv: illegal input sequence at position 8168

@tgriesser: That's all pretty interesting, however this ticket is not about bugs in the glibc iconv implementation. The CI project would be the wrong place to report those anyway (as well as the PHP project would be wrong).

This issue - as far as I have understood it - is about that the warning message gets _written into the logfiles_. If you run into the same problem and you don't want to have these errors logged, please see #342 for a proposed fix.

@ktomk I think the real issue is that rather than dropping the illegal characters as it's supposed to, the entire string is dropped...which isn't good.

I guess it doesn't seem to make sense to use a function which doesn't perform as documented (the //IGNORE flag should take care of the error and the characters) and invent a new level of logging to effectively "hide" the problem when mb_convert_encoding would get the same result without a problem

@tgriesser: You might be right about the OPs opening of this issue, I've read the latest comment of him and he addresses your direction. However:

Technically spoken: You can not tell which character is illegal or not if the encoding of the input string is undefined. So easy and clear.

If you signal `iconv` that the input _is_ UTF-8 but it's not, I would not expect that `iconv` let it pass. It looks like that PHP 5.4 finally does this properly by entirely not further on re-encode the input string. [Check the test with PHP 5.4](http://codepad.viper-7.com/Lgm4Vp). The result looks like it properly does not re-encode anything as the input was invalid (the only way to find out is to actually check for the warning or comparing string length of the input and output, as long as input had length but output has not, you can assume that the input was invalid, well that's a bit short but I think you get the idea).

The `//IGNORE` parameter however is only for the output encoding. That means: If (and only if) _the input is correctly encoded_, `iconv` can (and only then can) change it to _another_ encoding. If then the output encoding can not encode a code-point that is available in the input encoding, it will be dropped. `//IGNORE` is only a flagging on how to deal with missing code-points in the output encoding  (and that's [documented](http://php.net/manual/en/function.iconv.php)).

So rule of thumb: `//IGNORE` is about output encoding, **not** input encoding. The `//IGNORE` therefore is not in action at all yet. The warning is prior re-encoding. The warning is about checking the input and it's charset. If reported broken (not UTF-8), prior to PHP 5.4, it just did so assuming it's UTF-8. But that's violating the unicode standards and considered bad practice (an argument hard to ignore). You can't build proper computer systems with such defects. Gladly this has been fixed in PHP 5.4 and the input string is not used for re-encoding any longer.

I myself did misread this in the beginning as well. The notice is about the _input_ encoding (and not the output encoding). As we can already see in the warning that the input to the function is invalid, you can not expect that you get **any** result (even you did get results because of defects in the underlying routines of the software in PHP 5.2 and 5.3).

So maybe it's worth to actually talk about the concrete problems how they are visible to us: We have some input into our application and assume it's UTF-8. Now the warning tells us it's not. So it can't be hardly CI's job to fix your application. Please ensure that you always correctly process your applications input based on the concrete encoding the input data comming into your application is properly reflected.

@ktomk: Since CI runs everything through this function at runtime by default, based on the application wide `$config['charset'] = 'UTF-8';` setting it _is_ actually using the function as a fuzzy input filter to make sure that the incoming string is UTF-8 encoded by the time it hits the controller...and it isn't helpful if the string is truncated without throwing any sort of warning as to why.

Example: A POST is sent to a controller containing an illegal character and input is truncated at the beginning of the string (or just dropped entirely in php5.4 as you noted). The POST then goes on to fail a validation for the existence of input for that field and doesn't offer any explanation as to _why_

Potential Solution: Determining what the best method would be to determine/set the charset on a per-controller basis, or figuring out more about the actual intent of the filtering that CI employs when it runs everything through there by default in the app at runtime

I agree that all of the data should be checked, but if there isn't any warning (other than the error thrown by some variants of `iconv()` ) that can be a little confusing, especially to someone not as familiar with the default internals of CI
